questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with sudden onset abdominal pain in the epigastric region radiating to the back.  Investigations revealed elevated amylase levels and total WBC count. Identify the following sign seen on examination.
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. The sign shown in the image is Cullen’s sign. It is a bluish discoloration around the umbilicus.

Coopernail’s sign refers to the ecchymosis of the perineum and scrotum or labia due to pelvic fracture.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Acute Pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): Bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: Discolouration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): Dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Causes of Acute Pancreatitis

Common causes

  • Gallstones - most common
  • Alcohol
  • Post-ERCP (Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography)
  • Blunt trauma, abdomen
  • Post-operative (cardiothoracic, upper gastrointestinal, biliary)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction

Uncommon causes

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Deficiency of apolipoprotein CII
  • Pancreas divisum
  • Periampullary diverticulum
  • Vasculitis
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Ischemic–hypoperfusion states
  • Hereditary pancreatitis
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Renal failure

Drugs

  • L-Asparaginase
  • Steroids
  • Sulfonamides
  • Tetracycline
  • Valproate
  • Azathioprine
  • Anti-retroviral drugs
  • Estrogens
  • Thiazide diuretics

Rare causes

  • Autoimmune
  • Infections (mumps, coxsackie B, cytomegalovirus, parasite)
  • Malnutrition
  • Scorpion bite

questions.text: The image given below depicts a skin manifestation of a neurocutaneous disorder. Which of the following conditions given below are not associated with this neurocutaneous disorder?
questions.solution:
The image shows the shagreen patch seen in tuberous sclerosis. Out of the given options, Lisch nodules is not associated with tuberous sclerosis. Lisch nodules are associated with neurofibromatosis.

Clinical features of tuberous sclerosis:

  • CNS involvement (hallmark of tuberous sclerosis)
    • Subependymal nodules are lesions found along the wall of the lateral ventricles where they undergo calcification
    • These benign subependymal nodules lesions can grow into subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGA)
    • The characteristic brain lesion is a cortical tuber (white matter lesion)
  • Skin
    • Facial angiofibroma (adenoma sebaceum)
    • Periungual fibroma
    • Shagreen patch
    • Confetti skin lesions
  • Others
    • Renal angiomyolipoma

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with the findings below. The patient's mother gives a history of a fever the previous week along with bilateral conjunctival injection. She took the child to a clinic nearby and he was given some medications. Physical examination also reveals the presence of cervical lymphadenopathy. From the option below, choose the correct statements about his patient's diagnosis.
  1. Bilateral exudative conjunctivitis is a diagnostic feature of this condition
  2. The extremity changes seen in this patient are characteristic of the acute phase of illness
  3. Elevated acute phase reactants aids in the diagnosis
  4. Discrete oral lesions and tonsillar exudate are highly suggestive of the diagnosis
  5. Untreated cases result in long term complications
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of Kawasaki disease (KD). Elevated acute phase reactants aid in the diagnosis and untreated patients develop long-term cardiovascular complications that could potentially be fatal.

KD is the most common vasculitis in the pediatric age group. The condition reflects widespread inflammation of the medium-sized arteries. It is a self-limited condition and the acute-phase inflammation usually lasts about 12 days without therapy.

Clinical features:

  • Fever is the most consistent manifestation of KD. It remains above 101.3F during most of the illness and is minimally responsive to antipyretics
  • Bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis which begins within days of onset of fever is seen in the majority of these patients. It starts as a bulbar injection that appears as brilliant erythema that characteristically spares the limbus
  • Cracked red lips and a strawberry tongue is seen. It is a result of the sloughing of papillae on the tongue
  • A polymorphous rash, which starts as perineal erythema and desquamation, followed by macular, morbilliform, or targetoid skin lesions of the trunk and extremities. The rash may be confused with that of scarlet fever.
  • Changes in the extremities include swelling of the hands and feet which occurs during the acute phase of the illness and desquamation of the hands and feet (as seen in this patient) which are seen in the convalescent phase.
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy is seen in some patients but is not a consistent finding
  • The presence of distinct oral lesions and tonsillar exudate suggests and alternative diagnosis
  • Other nonspecific findings include arthritis, cardiovascular manifestations, diarrhea, irritability, cough, and decreased intake

Labs:

  • Elevated acute-phase reactants (ESR, CRP, ferritin, and reactive thrombocytosis)
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia
  • Pyuria
  • Hyponatremia
  • Abnormalities in the lipid profile

Diagnosis:

Requires the presence of fever and four of five clinical findings (conjunctivitis, mucosal changes, rash, extremity changes, and cervical lymphadenopathy) 

In addition, ECHO should be performed in all patients to rule out complications

Treatment:

  • Aspirin
  • IVIG to prevent complications

Complications:

20% of untreated patients develop cardiovascular sequelae, ranging from asymptomatic coronary arteritis to coronary artery ectasia, to giant coronary artery aneurysms (7 to 8 mm) leading to rupture or thrombosis, myocardial infarction, and sudden death.

questions.text: A patient with an acute attack of trigeminal neuralgia was treated with an anti-epileptic drug intravenously. The next day, he developed pain, swelling, and purple discolouration of his hand, distal to the site of injection as shown below. Identify the drug administered.
questions.solution:
The drug administered was phenytoin.

The clinical vignette of the patient developing pain, swelling, and purple discoloration of the skin, subsequent to intravenous administration of an antiepileptic drug for trigeminal neuralgia are indicative of purple glove syndrome due to phenytoin.

Purple glove syndrome is a rare complication that may follow the intravenous administration of phenytoin. It typically presents with pain, edema, and discoloration at the injection site that spreads distally.

Phenytoin is a hydantoin derivative that acts by slowing the rate of recovery of voltage-gated Na+ channels from inactivation and subsequently limits the repetitive firing of action potentials.

Phenytoin is extensively bound to plasma proteins, mainly albumin, and is metabolized by hepatic CYPs.

Despite its narrow therapeutic index, phenytoin is used in the treatment of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, complex partial seizures, status epilepticus, trigeminal neuralgia, and behavioral disorders.

 

Due to its ability to induce various CYPs, treatment with phenytoin can increase the metabolism of oral contraceptives that are metabolized by CYP3A4 and can lead to contraceptive failure.

It is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy as it can lead to fetal hydantoin syndrome. This syndrome is characterized by craniofacial anomalies like hypertelorism and epicanthal folds, short nose, and deep nasal bridge, malformed and low set ears, short neck, hypoplastic distal phalanges and underdevelopment of nails of fingers and toes, growth retardation, cognitive deficits and motor developmental delay. 

Other side effects of phenytoin include behavioural changes, increased frequency of seizures, gingival hyperplasia, megaloblastic anaemia, osteomalacia, hirsutism and hypersensitivity reactions.

Other options:

Option A: Carbamazepine is a sodium channel modulator like phenytoin used in the management of different types of focal and generalised tonic-clonic seizures. Its side effects include drowsiness, vertigo, ataxia, blurred vision and an increase in seizure frequency.

Option B: Zonisamide is a T-type calcium channel blocker used in the management of focal aware seizures and focal seizures with impaired awareness. Its side effects include somnolence, ataxia, anorexia, fatigue.

Option D: Clonazepam is a GABA receptor allosteric modulator that belongs to the benzodiazepine class of drugs and is used in the management of generalised absence seizures. It can result in lethargy, drowsiness, behavioural disturbances, withdrawal seizures and tolerance.

questions.text: A patient has been treated for the lesion shown in the picture below for the past 12 months but there has been no response to treatment. What is the next line of treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with keloid, refractory to the first line of treatment after 12 months of therapy should be considered for surgical exci­sion in combination with adjuvant therapy (postoperative electron beam irradiation).

A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound. Its etiology is unknown, but is associated with elevated levels of growth factor, deeply pigmented skin, and inherited tendency and certain areas of the body (triangle whose points are the xiphisternum and each shoulder tip).

Keloid scars do not improve spontaneously with time and excision of the keloid scar has a high rate of recurrence.

Treatment of keloids :

  • First-line treatments include silicones in combination with pressure therapy and intralesional corticosteroid injections.
  • Intralesional 5-fluorouracil, bleomycin, and verapamil should be used in accordance with established treatment protocols.
  • Refractory cases after 12 months of therapy should be considered for surgical excision in combination with adjuvant therapy.
  • Excision alone results in a high recurrence rate of 50% to 100% and enlargement of the keloid.
  • Immediate postoperative electron beam irradiation or brachytherapy with iridium-192 reduces recurrence rates. The risk of malignancy attributable to keloid radiation therapy is minimal.
  • An additional new invasive treatment modality is internal cryotherapy, in which a metal rod is introduced into the keloid and the subsequent extreme cooling leads to tissue necrosis.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male patient presents with mildly pruritic plaques in the left axilla for 2 weeks. Wood’s lamp examination showed coral red fluorescence. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above image along with coral-red fluorescence under Wood’s lamp is suggestive of erythrasma. It is caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum.

Erythrasma is a mild, chronic, superficial infection of the skin. It affects the axillae, groins, toe webs, inter-gluteal and submammary regions. Lesions may be symptomless or show mild discomfort and itching.

The lesions may be of irregular shape with sharp margins. They may start as smooth, red patches and then become brown. The lesions are more likely to be pruritic in the tropical regions and may be asymptomatic in the temperate climate. 

Coral‐red fluorescence with Wood’s light is due to coproporphyrin III and suggests erythrasma. The fluorescence may persist after the eradication of the disease. 

Treatment is required otherwise the lesions may persist with fluctuations in severity. Treatment involves topical clotrimazole and miconazole for two weeks. For more extensive lesions, erythromycin can be administered. Relapse can occur. In these cases, long-term povidone-iodine administered topically with drying agents are given. Photodynamic therapy can also be attempted. 

Other options:

Option A: Corynebacterium diphtheria causes diphtheria and the typical lesion early in the disease is a superficial ulcer, oval, rounded, or irregularly linear in shape with a clearly defined, overhanging edge. The ulcer may later become deeper and the edge becomes rolled, raised, and avascular. It is usually seen around the umbilicus, behind the ears, genito-crural flexure, or in the clefts.

Option C: Corynebacterium tenuis can give rise to trichomycosis axillaris, a superficial infection of axillary and pubic hairs with the formation of an adherent granular nodule which can be yellow, black, or red in color, on the hair shaft.

Option D: Bacillus anthracis causes anthrax, which upon introduction of endospores into areas of exposed skin like the face, neck, hands, or arms gives rise to a typical 'malignant pustule'. It starts as a papule that turns into a bulla on erythematous skin which ruptures to form a hemorrhagic crust surrounded by edema, erythema, and vesicles. The lesions may be single or many.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image.
questions.solution:
The condition given in the image is ankyloblepharon. It is the adhesion between the margins of the upper and lower eyelids.

It may occur as a congenital anomaly or as acquired adhesions after healing of chemical burns, ulcers, or traumatic wounds of the lid margins. 

Treatment is the excision of the adhesions between lid margins. Epithelial grafts should be used if adhesions extend to angles.

Other options:

Option A: Symblepharon is the adhesion between the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva in which the eyelids become adherent to the eyeball.

The image given below shows symblepharon.

Option C: Congenital blepharophimosis is a condition in which the extent of the palpebral fissure is decreased. It can be congenital or acquired and is due to a vertical skin fold at the lateral canthus. No treatment is required. In some cases, canthoplasty is done.

Option D: Congenital ptosis is associated with developmental defect and weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) muscle. Drooping of one or both of the upper eyelids is seen since birth. Lid lag on downward gaze is present. Treatment involves surgical correction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented with a history of tremors, palpitation, and difficulty in closing his eyes for the past 1 month. On examination, you note the following finding as shown in the image given below. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The given image shows lid retraction in the right eye, which is known as Dalrymple's sign.

It is the commonest and earliest sign of Grave's ophthalmopathy. It is due to overactivity of levator aponeurosis and Müller's muscle. Here the upper lid margin is at level with or above the superior limbus, causing the upper sclera to become visible (scleral show).

Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder that results in hyperthyroidism. In this condition, autoantibodies bind to thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptors and stimulate the secretion of thyroid hormone. 

Thyroid ophthalmopathy or thyroid eye disease can be seen in Graves' disease or even in euthyroid/ hypothyroid patients. Women and smokers are at higher risk of developing Grave's ophthalmopathy (otherwise known as thyroid eye disease). 

Thyroid function tests and a thyroid autoantibody assay should be done to assess thyroid hormone status. 

Control of hyperthyroidism is effective in management. Injecting botulinum toxin to levator aponeurosis and Müller's muscle may be done as a temporary measure. 

The other options are all signs associated with Grave's disease but do not correlate with the given image.

Related Pearl: Werner classification

  • It is well known by the acronym of NO SPECS.
  • Each grade is further subdivided as 0-4 and a-c.

questions.text: Choose the correctly matched pair among the following nail changes with their respective diseases.
questions.solution:
Image 1 is correctly matched. It shows trachonychia, which is most commonly seen in alopecia areata.

Trachyonychia presents as a rough surface affecting the entire nail plate and up to 20 nails (20‐nail dystrophy). It is mainly associated with alopecia areata, psoriasis, and lichen planus.

Other nail findings in alopecia areata:
  • fine stippled pitting of the nails
  • atrophic dystrophy
 
Image 2 shows onychomycosis

Distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis is the most common pattern of infection. It usually presents as a yellow or white patch of discoloration, at the free edge of the nail plate, and near the lateral nail fold.

 
Image 3 shows nail pitting with subungual oil drops 

Nail pitting is the most frequent change seen in psoriasis. Nail bed disease can be seen as subungual oil drops which are pathognomonic for psoriasis.

 

Image 4 shows the pup tent sign, elevation of nail in shape of tent, which is seen in lichen planus.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image: Trachyonychia

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

questions.text: Identify the test shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
The test shown in the given image is Adson's test done for thoracic outlet syndrome.

Thoracic outlet syndrome occurs due to compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus(C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels between the clavicle and the first rib. This produces neurological vascular symptoms. The compression can be due to an extra rib or due to abnormal scalene muscles, etc.

Clinical features:

Even though the anomalies responsible for this condition are congenital, symptoms appear during the third decade. This is because the blood vessels that supply the trunk level of the brachial plexus become less compliant in the third decade. 

The patient presents with pain and paresthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm and the medial two fingers. Ulnar clawing and wasting of the intrinsic muscles of the hand may be seen. Vascular signs are less common but the presence of unilateral Raynauds phenomenon should raise suspicion of thoracic outlet syndrome. 

Tests for thoracic outlet syndrome are provocative maneuvers that are performed to reproduce the signs and symptoms of this condition.

These provocative tests are not sensitive nor specific to making a diagnosis of thoracic outlet syndrome.

Treatment:

Conservative management consists of shoulder muscle strengthening, postural training, and analgesics for pain.

Surgical management is indicated if there is severe pain, obvious muscle wasting, or presence of vascular disturbances. The cervical rib is removed via a supraclavicular or trans-axillary approach. 

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of dysphagia. She also says that her hands and feet turn cold and blue when she goes to visit her daughter who lives in a hill station. Her examination findings are as given in the image. What is the earliest cutaneous manifestation that can be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of systemic sclerosis. The earliest cutaneous manifestations in systemic sclerosis are non-pitting edema and puffiness of the fingers, hands, and face. 

The image shows a woman with mask-like facies with stretched, shiny skin, and loss of normal facial lines, microstomia, and resorption of distal phalanges of the fingers. The clinical history describes Raynaud's phenomenon (hands and feet turn cold and blue in cold climate) and hence, the probable diagnosis is systemic sclerosis.

Systemic sclerosis is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4: 1 female predominance.

Cutaneous features:

  • Hands and feet - Raynaud's phenomenon, non-pitting edema, painful ulcerations which heal with pitted scars, sclerodactyly, contractures, loss of sweat glands, bone resorption.
  • Face - periorbital edema, mask-like facies, telangiectasia, and diffuse hyperpigmentation.
  • Trunk - firm, shiny, and thickened skin.
  • Reduced hair growth is seen.

Systemic features:

  • GIT- dysphagia, GERD, diminished peristalsis, malabsorption
  • Lungs- pulmonary fibrosis and alveolitis
  • Heart- cardiac conduction defects, heart failure
  • Kidney- uremia, malignant hypertension
  • Musculoskeletal- weakness, carpal tunnel syndrome.

Using modified Rodnan skin score (MRSS). the degree of skin sclerosis is scored from 0 to 3 by manual palpation at 17 different body sites. The maximum score that can be attained is 51. This method has been shown to correlate with skin biopsy thickness, disease severity, and long‐term outcome of the disease.

The scoring of each skin region is determined by skin thickness and tethering:
0 = Normal
1 = Possible thickening
2 = Unable to pinch the skin
3 = Unable to move the skin (which is fixed to deeper tissues)

This modified score does not include the assessment of the neck and back. If these areas are included, the maximum attainable score increases to 57.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of the lesion shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the lesion is a neuropathic ulcer.

A neuropathic ulcer is one that occurs due to peripheral neuropathy. In peripheral neuropathy, lack of sensation over the pressure points leads to cumulative microtrauma, minor wounds, or cuts that go unnoticed eventually developing into ulcers. They are painless, punched out with regular margins, on the plantar surface of the foot, and show the presence of calluses. 

Management of neuropathic ulcer: Debridement of all necrotic or hyperkeratotic wound tissue, proper cultures to be done if an infection is suspected for microbiological analysis. Any ulcerations subjected to sustained pressure should be subjected to pressure reduction by mechanical offloading which includes wedge shoes, total contact cast, cast walkers, etc.

questions.text: A dentist presents with painful lesions on his fingertip as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely etiology for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing vesicles and cloudy blisters at the pulp of fingers is suggestive of herpetic whitlow. It is caused by the herpes simplex virus.

Herpetic whitlow is most commonly contracted by dental workers and medical workers exposed to oral secretions. Clinical features include painful deep vesicles at the site of inoculation (in this case fingertips) which coalesce to form large bullae or a honeycomb appearance. Fever and constitutional symptoms are mild.

Whitlow can lead to necrosis of the distal 4/5th of the terminal phalanx. It does not cause necrosis of the entire phalanx because the proximal 1/5th escapes as in this part the artery does not cross the fibrous septa.

The pulp space of fingers contains subcutaneous fat arranged in tight compartments. These compartments are formed by fibrous septa extending from the skin to the periosteum of the terminal phalanx.

Diagnosis of herpes simplex virus:

  • Most sensitive test- HSV DNA- PCR (can differentiate between HSV 1 and 2)
  • Most definitive test- virus isolation using human diploid fibroblast in which cytopathic changes can be observed as early as 24 - 48 hours.
  • Microscopy - Tzanck smear, which is a rapid, diagnostic method, shows Tzanck cells. These are multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogenously stained ground-glass chromatin. Intranuclear type A inclusion bodies may also be seen.

The image given below shows Tzanck cells.

Tzanck smear is also used in the diagnosis of Hailey-Hailey disease, Darier’s disease, hand-foot-and-mouth disease, etc.

Whitlow or pulp space infections are treated by a lateral incision and drainage. Its complications are: 

  • Ischemic necrosis of the distal 4/5th of terminal phalanx due to vessel occlusion.
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Flexor tenosynovitis
  • Septic arthritis of DIP (distal interphalangeal joint)

Other forms of inoculation type of herpes are:

  • Herpes gladitorium in wrestlers where vesicles can be present on the scalp, face, and upper trunk
  • Scrumpox is seen in rugby players due to facial contact.

questions.text: A woman who was started on treatment for leprosy recently presents with the following painful lesions that developed over the existing hypopigmented lesions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Development of ulcerating lesions over the leprosy skin lesions following initiation of treatment for leprosy is suggestive of a severe type 1 lepra reaction/ reversal reaction. 

Lepra 1 reactions are due to an enhanced cell-mediated immune response to M. leprae. They usually present abruptly with redness and inflammation of existing lesions but can cause ulceration in severe cases. It occurs due to a large amount of M. leprae antigens in these patients which results in prolonged and repeated reactions during treatment. They are commonly seen in the borderline spectrum but are most severe in borderline lepromatous leprosy.

Another form of lepra reaction with ulcerating lesions is the Lucio reaction. It is a rare type of lepra reaction that is seen in patients with lepra bonita. It is often the initial presentation in untreated patients. It is common over extremities and spreads in an ascending fashion. It presents as tender nodules that form jagged ulcers.

questions.text: A patient complains of hair loss over the back of her head. On examination, a 2 cm area of complete, smooth, circular hair loss with distinct margins and exclamation mark hairs is seen without scaling or inflammation. On further examination, the nail finding is shown in the image below. Which of the following is false about the condition responsible for this finding?

choices.text: Non- pigmemted hair is primarily affected
Condition can be associated with thyroiditis

questions.solution:
The image shows fine stippled pitting of nails, and the non-scarring type of hair loss associated with it is alopecia areata. The false statement about it is that non-pigmented hair is primarily affected.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is a T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease. It is associated with several autoimmune diseases including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis.

It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis). The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia. Some broken hairs can be seen, which are called exclamation marks. They are easily extractable. It preferentially affects pigmented hair and spares non-pigmented or white hair.

A perifollicular and intrafollicular inflammatory cell infiltrate that is focused in and around the hair bulb can be seen in anagen follicles near the edges of growing regions of alopecia areata. The predominant component of the inflammatory infiltration is activated T lymphocytes, with predominant CD4 cells, macrophages, Langerhans cells, and cells that exhibit NK cell markers.

Spontaneous remission occurs in a majority of patients with hair loss that is patchy and is of shorter duration. Topical steroids like clobetasol can be useful in patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional steroids are the most effective treatment for patchy alopecia areata. 

Severe and long-standing alopecia areata requires oral corticosteroids.

questions.text: A young girl presents with leukotrichia and lesions as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows areas of localized, unilateral depigmented macules. This feature, along with a history of leukotrichia suggest that the patient is suffering from segmental vitiligo. It occurs due to a lack of melanocytes in the basal layer of the epidermis.

It is a localised depigmentation that occurs due to a progressive loss in the melanocytes. It is classified as

  • Segmental vitiligo- which appears as unilateral maculae in a segmented or band-shaped pattern
  • Non-segmental vitiligo- which appears as bilateral maculae distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body

The lesions become apparent between 20-30 years of age. 

Hypopigmented macules in vitiligo are commonly found in the hips, dorsum of the hands/fingers, feet, elbows, knees, and ankle areas. These are the areas of repeated friction. Rarely there may be complete vitiligo (vitiligo universalis), or trichrome vitiligo where there are areas of depigmentation, hyperpigmentation, along with the normal skin are present. The Koebner phenomenon is the development of lesions at the site of trauma on the uninvolved skin.

Several autoimmune conditions can be associated with vitiligo. They are:

  • Thyroid disease (hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism )
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Addison disease
  • Diabetes
  • Hypoparathyroidism

Under the Wood's lamp examination the depigmented areas emit a bright blue-white fluorescence and appear sharply demarcated. 

Treatment involves cosmetic camouflage and the use of sunscreen. The topical application of corticosteroids is the first line of treatment. Topical calcineurin inhibitors like pimecrolimus, tacrolimus have also shown to be successful. Psoralen photochemotherapy, khellin, selective ultraviolet B therapy are used as second-line treatment. In patients who do not respond to this treatment, surgical grafting techniques can be used, where the melanocytes from a normal pigmented area are transferred to a non pigmented area. In patients with extensive vitiligo where only a few pigmented areas are left, depigmentation can be done.

 

 

Other options: 

A) Focal vitiligo:

These are small isolated depigmented lesions that are neither segmentally distributed nor evolved into non-segmental lesions after 1-2 years. The focal vitiligo along with isolated mucosal lesions on one site are considered as undetermined /unclassified vitiligo.

 

C) Piebaldism:

It commonly presents with a white V-shaped forelock. it is caused due to the impaired migration of melanocytes to the skin, resulting in hypopigmented patches.

 

D) Nevus depigmentosus:

It is a congenital pigmentary disorder that presents with a non-progressive hypopigmented macule. It usually is present from birth or early childhood and remains stable throughout life.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of fever, myalgia, and severe arthralgia. She also developed pigmentation on the nose after a few days of the onset of these symptoms as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history of fever, myalgia, severe arthralgia, and nose hyperpigmentation (chik sign) points towards a diagnosis of chikungunya. 

Chik sign refers to a central facial pigmentation predominantly on the nose which develops during the acute phase of the disease. It helps in the retrospective diagnosis of Chikungunya infection. It most commonly affects the nose and cheeks. It appears as the fever subsides.

Chikungunya fever is due to infection with Chikungunya virus, spread by mosquitos and direct contact between humans. The Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes are the most common vectors.

It presents as an acute onset of fever, arthralgia, and myalgia with other flu symptoms such as headache, loss of appetite, and nausea. A maculopapular rash develops, which is more pronounced on the trunk. The rash may occasionally progress to petechiae and purpura. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical, however, a definitive diagnosis can be made by the detection of IgM antibodies in the serum with ELISA or RTPCR.

Treatment is supportive with acetaminophen and NSAIDs. The rash can be managed with saline compresses and emollients. Persistent non-healing ulcers can be managed by topical or systemic antibiotics. Most of the skin lesions resolve within 2 weeks.

Other options:

Option A- Hyperpigmentation of the centrofacial face (nose and cheeks) mimics melasma and may be misdiagnosed if proper history is not taken. Melasma is hyperpigmented macules of the face that increase after sun exposure. 

The following image shows the hyperpigmentation of the face seen in melasma.

Option B- Melanocytic papillomatous nevi are acquired dermal nevi that are very common. They protrude from the skin surface and may be pigmented or skin-colored. Upon histological examination, they exhibit nevus cell nests in the dermis. Therapy consists of excision, shave excision, or laser therapy. 

Option C- Actinic keratosis is a pre-malignant lesion that consists of crusty, scaly patches of skin. It is associated with UV light exposure and is therefore associated with solar damage to the surrounding skin. 

The following image shows the scaly patches of skin suggestive of actinic keratosis of the scalp.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the conditions given below?

choices.text: It is more common in girls than boys
Haab striae is seen in late stages
Prognosis is worse if glaucoma is present since birth.

questions.solution:
Congenital glaucoma occurs more often in boys than in girls and is commonly seen bilaterally.

The first sign may be an edema of the cornea with watering of the eyes and marked photo­ phobia. At a later stage, rupture of Descemet's membrane causes more discrete corneal opacities (Haab’s striae.)

The Prognosis is

  • Worst – if glaucoma is present since birth.
  • Best – if present from 2 months to 1 year.
